info.name: OS1 Postman Collection v3.7.1
info.description:
# Postman Troubleshooting Guide

## Resolving Unresolved Variables

If you have variables in your Postman requests that are showing as unresolved, follow these steps:

1. Make sure the variable is defined in the OS1 APIs environment.
2. Check that the variable name matches exactly, including case, to where it is used.
3. Verify the variable is not overwritten or masked by a variable of the same name in a higher scope.
4. Try referencing the variable in other places to test if it is defined properly.
5. Re-create the variable if needed to resolve the issue.
    

## Incorrect BaseURLs

If requests are failing due to incorrect BaseUrls:

1. Double check that the current environment selected matches the API you are trying to hit.
2. Edit the BaseUrl value in the environment and replace it with the correct API endpoint base path.
3. Resend the request using the updated environment.
4. Update the BaseUrl inside at the environment level if neccessary.
    

## Populating the OS1 Environment File

To populate the OS1 environment file with variables for API calls:

1. Set the **OS1 APIs** environment as active.
2. Define variables specific to the OS1 API like username, password, client ID, etc.
3. Add the {{BaseUrl}} variable with the OS1 API endpoint.
4. Use {{variables}} in the URLs and headers of OS1 requests.
5. Refer to the Postman documentation for more tips on effectively using variables.

query.description: (Required) comma separated lat and lon which denotes the starting position OR the address of the source point
(Required) comma separated lat and lon which denotes the ending position OR the address of the destination point
time in epoch seconds at which the vehicle is scheduled to depart from the origin(s). The provided time can be either current time or a later time. It cannot be in the past
(Required) denotes the mode of transportation. Should be oneOf ["driving", "walking", "bicycling"]

Restrictions are indicated by use of the avoid parameter, and an argument to that parameter indicating the restriction to avoid. Comma separated. The following restrictions are supported tolls", "highways", "ferries", "indoor". Default - none. Example- tolls,highways

Specifies the assumptions to use when calculating time in traffic

**best_guess:** (default) indicates that the returned duration_in_traffic should be the best estimate of travel time given what is known about both historical traffic conditions and live traffic.

**pessimistic:** indicates that the returned duration_in_traffic should be longer than the actual travel time on most days, though occasional days with particularly bad traffic conditions may exceed this value.

**optimistic:** indicates that the returned duration_in_traffic should be shorter than the actual travel time on most days, though occasional days with particularly good traffic conditions may be faster than this value.

if trafficModel is provided in request, then departureTime is mandatory
(Required) json string with the callback details. If provided, the API response will be sent to the callback url in an async manner.

Restrictions are indicated by use of the avoid parameter, and an argument to that parameter indicating the restriction to avoid. Comma separated. The following restrictions are supported tolls", "highways", "ferries", "indoor". Default - none. Example- tolls,highways

Specifies the assumptions to use when calculating time in traffic

**best_guess:** (default) indicates that the returned duration_in_traffic should be the best estimate of travel time given what is known about both historical traffic conditions and live traffic.

**pessimistic:** indicates that the returned duration_in_traffic should be longer than the actual travel time on most days, though occasional days with particularly bad traffic conditions may exceed this value.

**optimistic:** indicates that the returned duration_in_traffic should be shorter than the actual travel time on most days, though occasional days with particularly good traffic conditions may be faster than this value.

if trafficModel is provided in request, then departureTime is mandatory
(Required) json string with the callback details. If provided, the API response will be sent to the callback url in an async manner.

request.description:
Register the app configurations.
### **Permissions**: 
Permissions are the access rights needed to control who can do what within the app. This list specifies the permissions required to access particular resources. 
                
For instance, if your app exposes User-related events and provides an API for fetching user details at '/api/v1/users/:userId', the permissions necessary to access this endpoint should be added here. You can find them in your app's AAA YAML. 
                
Subscribers who want to receive events from this app must have at least one of the role that includes these listed permissions. This will be used to control only authorized apps are able to subscribe to your events.
        

### **Name**: 
User friendly name for the app, subscribers will use this name to subscribe to the app's published events. It will be automatically fetched from dev portal. Listing-id of the app will be used as app name.

request.description:
Register the event configurations. 
Filtering will work in following sequence.
1. Filter on the eventType(mandatory)
2. Filter on the type (optional) e.g. users, vehicles
3. Apply additional filtering using filter logic (optional)

**getAPIPath**: API path example through which the resource represented by this event will be accessible. This will be used for checking whether subscriber app has access to this app or not. e.g. /app/api/v2/users/51941b1e-c356-4563-a245-66438a19585e"

**Note**: App can publish max 20 unique events per event Type.
Also, Max 5 subscribers are allowed per Event.

request.description:
Get the subscriptions executions.

**Execution Storage and Expiry**:

  Executions are stored within the system and have a Time-to-Live (TTL) expiry set to 7 days. 
  This means that execution records older than 7 days are automatically removed from the storage. 
  
  When using the date query parameter, the endpoint retrieves executions within the specified date, keeping in line with the 7-day storage limit. 

  Max 20 executions logs can be fetching per request.
